description:
Podospora bellae-mahoneyi is a species of coprophilous (dung-inhabiting) ascomycete fungus. It belongs to the genus Podospora, which is classified within the Lasiosphaeriaceae family of the Ascomycota phylum.

This species was first described scientifically in 1987 based on specimens collected from dung samples in the United States. It is characterized by its small, dark-colored perithecia (fruiting bodies) that develop on the surface of dung. The asci (spore-bearing structures) within the perithecia contain eight ascospores, which are brown in color and possess distinctive ornamentations on their surfaces.

Podospora bellae-mahoneyi is known to play a role in the decomposition of organic matter, particularly animal dung, as part of the fungal community inhabiting these nutrient-rich substrates. Its ecological function involves the breakdown of complex organic compounds and the recycling of nutrients in terrestrial ecosystems.
